https://www.cbsnews.com/news/father-of-peeps-bob-born-dies-at-98/
>Bob Born was born in New York City on Sept. 29, 1924. His father, Sam Born, was a Russian immigrant who had founded Just Born Inc., a small candy company, in 1923. The family later moved to Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, where Just Born is still based. Bob Born graduated from Lehigh University with a degree in engineering physics. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served as a radar specialist and a lieutenant on a destroyer in the Pacific. Later, the Navy sent him to the University of Arizona and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for graduate work in math and physics.

>Born applied to medical school and was accepted, but while he was waiting for his classes to begin, he went to work at Just Born. He fell in love with the candy business and decided to stay. In 1953, Just Born acquired Rodda Candy Co., a jelly bean maker that had a side business producing shaped marshmallow candies by hand. At the time, it took about 27 hours to make the marshmallows. Bob Born saw the candies' potential, so he and an engineer at the company designed and built a machine to make them in less than six minutes. The company still uses a version of that machine.

>Seventy years later, Peeps remain Just Born's most recognizable candy brand, the company says. Just Born makes around 2 billion Peeps each year, or enough to circle the globe twice. It sells the most at Easter, but also has versions sold for Halloween, Valentine's Day and other holidays. Bob Born also came up with the recipe for another popular Just Born candy, Hot Tamales. Just Born also makes Mike and Ike fruit chews and Goldenberg's Peanut Chews.

>Bob Born became Just Born's president in 1959 and held the role for more than 30 years. He spent most of his retirement in Florida, where he led a literacy program and enjoyed hobbies including photography. He was active until a few months before he died, when he had a difficult recovery after a hard fall.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880015
1 rabbit
1 spoonful of butter
1 carrot
1 onion
2 laurel leaves
3 cloves
1 sprig of thyme
1 bottle of dry white whine
4 spoons of oil
pepper grains
salt

Prepare the rabbit beforehand, to make sure you can time the final step depending on when you need it ready.

That's it. Doesn't really give much in the way of a recipe, and everything else is just what everyone does.

An egg dumplings recipe that my mother got from her grandmother which originated from either Germany or Russia. Can't remember where exactly. Simply take a couple eggs, a couple tablespoons of milk and cup or 2 of flour, beat the eggs and milk together, add flour and beat until thick, scoop out some portions and throw them into boiling water pot and cook for 15-30 minutes. When done cooking scoop out dumplings with spoon with a strainer to remove water and put in bowl applying butter and pepper to your liking.

Been thinking about changing the recipe up abit and adding more too it but I think it's pretty peak poor people food as is.

Cereal, instant ramen, homemade pizzas using the cheapest pizza dough mix, jarred sauce, and store brand cheese available, canned ravioli, spaghetti-os, sandwiches, everything the cheapest possible off-brand from the discount grocery store that only sold whatever cheap shit they could get that week.

I was fully aware how shit our situation was from a pretty young age, decided when I moved out I wasn't going to do that shit anymore and started teaching myself to cook immediately.

posts.com: Grew up almost hillbilly poor but never realized it. My mom had a nice but small house. We ate a lot of beans and pasta and eggs from our coop. I look back on it all fondly

Two embarrassing stories, our school had some kind of park outing. They ordered those giant 9 foot subway sandwiches for the class. Everyone was supposed to chip in a couple of dollars but my brother and I had nothing so we had to eat our pb&j sandwiches while all the other kids feasted.
Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.
Now that I think about it that family were kind of assholes. That wasn't the first time they fucked with me. They knew we were dirt poor and they were rich. Probably why they never let me hang out with their kid again after that.
Being a poor kid living in a relatively well off neighborhood was hell. Everyone I knew at school/church was always going on ski trips and shit and we never got to go along with anything.

what moka does differently is take away factors of control from your brew.
no: pressure, tamping, control of water input, control of water temperature, control of temperature of the overall vessel.
you pray the water raises evenly through the coffee bed, you pray nothing gets burned.
that in mind, espresso is not the be all end all of brewing methods. its a useful concentrated base drink to make many other drinks out of. but if you want the best out of your beans, you learn to do a proper pourover.

>>18873831
If you want single serve, I believe a standard ceramic v60 would do the trick. In my opinion, kalita wave style filters do best when there is an airgap on the sidewall, so i'm not too fond of my origami and prefer an actual wave or stagg x. Your personal taste will vary.
If you want to make multiple cups, seriously consider a 8-10 cup chemex. The funnex is an option, but I feel there is better single serve drippers out there.

>>18873838
The silt is part of the experience for a french press, but if it really bothers you consider getting a 200 micron filter device. It feels kinda wasteful discarding some of your grounds, but will negate your issue. You can also use the filter to help prevent paper/cloth filter clogging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873838
Watch for fines in your grinds. Give the brewing grinds a stir and time to settle to the bottom. Pour slowly and maybe discard the last couple ounces. You might even also spoon off the first crema as I find that really improves the clarity of the cup. The FP shouldn't rely on the screen. It helps but gravity does most of your filtering.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18875263
There's really no point in spending more on a French Press. Most of the "premium" features you'd get on more expensive models (borosilicate or stainless vs cheap soda-lime glass; dual wall/insulation vs single wall; etc) are kind of pointless in a French Press. Because it's an immersion brewer, you shouldn't be leaving the grounds and water in there long enough for heat loss to be an issue, and even the cheapest, thinnest soda-lime glass won't experience catastrophic thermal shock at 100°C. Now, having said all that, if my cheap chinkshit French Press broke, I'd probably replace it with an Espro P3. I'd be interested in seeing how/if the dual mesh basket affects the brew.

I've never had it before, so I don't know what a proper one is meant to taste like, and I didn't have the proper equipment, so I ended up putting my tiny 350ml milk pitcher on the stovetop, but it was actually surprisingly nice. It was very "intense," which I imagine is the point, but it wasn't bitter or under/overextracted at all. I didn't have the nice foam/crema on top, and I don't know if that's due to improper grind or improper heating vessel, but it was quite a pleasant experience. Now I'm tempted to find a place around me that makes Turkish coffee to see what it's actually supposed to taste like, and how close I got using my poorfag method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879327
Cool, dark, temp stable place. Opaque container would be ideal, but its more about minimizing air exchange for longer term storage. I use mason jars with (salvaged)one way valves for the coffees I'm currently resting, then divide them out into convenient portions to vac seal and freeze. The coffees I'm currently drinking are in kurasu cans. Bought them because they're cute, but I'd imagine the ceramic airscapes are much better.
https://espressoaf.com/guides/storage.html
https://youtu.be/K0JWuhE8a-w
https://youtu.be/UOD188lZRy0
>And how long does it take for an opened bag of coffee to go stale?
Depends on the roast and how often you're exposing it to fresh oxygen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879755
Sort of depends on what you want to drink, and how much work you're willing to put in to drink it. An Aeropress will get you brewed coffee; users will claim you can get espresso out of it, but they're going to hell for lying. It's far easier to use than a Mini/Nano, though. The Mini/Nano has the added benefit of taking pods, if you don't want to carry around a grinder or pre-ground coffee, but since it's closer to an actual espresso machine, it'll be more finnicky about temperature, while also being more work to produce coffee. I don't use either an Aeropress or a Mini/Nanopresso, but I do use a Picopresso as a daily driver espresso machine, but I can't imagine using that at school, but that machine is far more finnicky about all of the various coffee variables, since it's an actual espresso machine. For the record, I think Wacaco, the company behind all of the various [word for small]-presso products is also Chinese. And if you think a device similar to a Minipresso is a pain in the ass to use, I can't imagine a Mini or Nano being any less of a pain in the ass.

>>18879035
Very little meat. Very little cheese. Almost entirely plants. Most of their protein came from beans.
Mostly their diet consisted of extremely coarse, unpleasant barley bread (easier to grow than wheat, but it tastes bad).
Generally peasants wouldn't be malnourished– there'd be enough food for most of the year, but consistent periods of severe hunger during lean years. Medieval commoners were around 7 inches shorter on average than people are today.
All the animal products, nuts, and other proteins that allow people to grow to a healthy size were too resource intensive for the poor to afford; even those that could access them were often better off selling them for more grain.
This improved significantly after the black plague killed a third of the population. Europe was heavily overpopulated in the high middle ages relative to its technological carrying capacity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879035
Due to crop rotation being necessary they ate a lot of beans and similar things. Bread being another staple, there is a reason they mention daily bread in the lord's prayer it's not just a metaphor. A lot of root vegetables during the winter, with a variety of seasonal crops. Fish was very important as well and a reason beyond trade for coastal cities being the largest in general.
As for meat most of the animals you raised for other things such as milk, wool and eggs so you would only eat them when they were too old to provide these things giving poor quality and though meat. So quality beef and lamb etc was pretty much only for the rich. Pigs however were raised for meat even by the lower classes as you could have them find food in woods you otherwise wouldn't get any food out of anyway. Hunted meat would also be had in the rural areas. A large part of why the norman king's forest laws were so hated in England were so hated is because it prevented the common people from having access to these two types of meat which they had earlier.

To start out with, prioritizing what's cheap:
rice,
beans,
lentils,
powdered milk (they sell their own nonfat powdered milk apparently, I assume nonfat to make it last much longer)
powdered eggs
canned meat
coconut oil (all saturated so it'll last a while)
agave nectar or sugar because they're cheap, also molasses because it's cheap, has actual vitamins in it, and I like it and don't understand why other people don't like molasses.
also sweetened condensed milk because it's great
Dates,
candied pineapple,
chili dried mango,
candied ginger,
salt, garlic powder, onion powder, pepper, nutmeg, allspice, paprika, chili powder, hot sauces, chocolate, whatever else I can think of to raise morale in an emergency. Pepper and nutmeg would obviously be whole because fresh ground is so much better.

Alternate strategy: a couple of female Nigerian dwarf goats, half a dozen hens, and a bunch of seeds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879027
none of them have capsaicin. we could put them into 3 rough categories
piperine: peppercorns and long pepper
homovanillyl ketones: ginger and grains of paradise
isothiocyanates: mustard seeds wasabi and horseradish, black mustard having most of the volatile allyl isothiocyanate that gets into your nose
the piperine type of spicyness probably comes closest to peppers, but yeah its not the same. black mustard seed comes closer in potency to chili peppers but its a very different type of spicyness

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

The thing about mushrooms and rinsing;
If you're cooking at home you can rinse them and cook with them right away and it's fine. They won't get soggy.

You're running a restaurant, however, you might get a big crate of mushrooms and Tuesday and clean them all so they're ready to use for the rest of the week. If you rinse those with water they might be soggy and sad by the end of the week, so you have to clean those with a dry brush instead.

>>18876997
What are you talking about? Most mushrooms in the grocery store (white button, portobello, baby bello, "stuffing mushrooms") are agaricus. They're highly carcinogenic if eaten raw. Scientists use agaritine to give rats tumors when they want to study cancer, that's how reliably carcinogenic it is.

Another info I have about grocery store mushrooms is that all the oyster species, such as blue/yellow/pink/pearl as well as the king trumpet, will trigger a serious allergic reaction in about 10% of the population if eaten raw. Basically if you're at all allergic to mold or mold spores then you're probably allergic to all the oyster species. It's not recommended to find out whether you fall into this camp.

>>18879288
Mushroom cultivator here. The procedure is that you make "grain spawn" (mycelium-colonized grains) as a way to quickly propagate mycelium. Then you use the grain spawn to inoculate larger bags of less nutritious bulk substrate for fruiting. Nobody fruits from grain, especially not commercially, because it would be a preposterous waste of money. White button mushrooms and portabellas are fruited in a sterilized compost/manure mixture. Yes it's cow shit and yes it's also literally clean enough to eat. You should wash mushrooms when they've been in the grocery store because people coughed on them, not because of the shit.

posts.com: Matapa is a south-east African dish made from cassava leaves. Might not look like much and yet I would argue its the ultimate African comfort food. Matapa tastes so good that its commonly served at various celebrations like weddings. It is served with ugali (African polenta) or rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18868118
I am Kenyan, so of course I don't know much about West African cuisine. However, I have cohabitated with Nigerians briefly, and they seem to like really greasy food that is on the spicy side. They also love cooking with palm oil. Their favourite dishes are a cassava-based mash (fufu) and they eat a lot of meat, mostly beef. Jollof is a big hit there, but everyone knows this already. They also love pastry.
East Africa's food, specifically Kenya's, is very legume, leaf vegetable and cereal-heavy. We drink a lot of tea. We also drink a lot of beer. We have really good beer. We eat a lot of beef.
Fish is popular in the Lake Victoria and Indian Ocean regions, but I wouldn't call it a staple. We don't drink coffee even though we are famous for our coffee exports. Chicken is a delicacy, but it's too expensive, so it's a red-letter day kind of food.
Our staple food is definitely maize. The most popular form of maize is what you would call gritz, or polenta that's very firm. We call it ugali. All of east africa loves it, and even Zambians, South Africans have it regularly. It's basically our form of fufu.
The Indian ocean coast has very middle-eastern/mediterranean-influenced cuisine, and Tanzania is very similar to our coast in cultural and culinary influence. Parts of Uganda are very similar to our Lake Victorian coast, and their staple food is bananas.
We eat pork, but mostly in form of sausage. Raw pork isn't a hot grocery item here. We don't eat bush meat, that's an American savage peculiarity, except if an occassional elephant or hippo decides to fuck with and/or kill people, then bush meat is what's for supper.
We have multiple KFC outlets in every major city, a few McD's, countless pizza parlours and several Burger Kings. These are very popular with younger people (up to 35 years) but most people can't afford to eat at these places everyday. Taking a Kenyan girl to these joints will get you laid, guaranteed.
Also, don't ever come to Kenya. We're full.

I worked for an airline catering company. LSG. Bizarre how all that shit gets on and removed from flights. Most is frozen. Everything has strict specs for weight, count, etc. Fruit n cheese plates, salads, and first class for specific airlines is fresh made in house. Delta, United, Alaskan, and British Airways are pretty solid and fresh. Everything American Airlines is frozen. The bizarre amount of special meals available was irritating. Vegan, veg, Muslim, kosher, etc. Kosher meals came 100 percent frozen and shrink wrapped on serving trays. The rest are a pain. Nobody adhered to any of the Muslim meal/kitchen guidelines, but the end result fit the parameters.

there is so much talk of airplane food being bland, myself, i loved the airplane food, perhaps it was the excitement, civilian airplanes are in my eyes among the most beautiful machines man has ever built, sitting comfortably at ~10km altitude, oftentimes with a magical view, hearing the sound of the wind rushing over the airframe, hearing the muffled sound of people talking, having a trey served with various little food items.. to me, it was the whole package, it was the experience i appreciated, it crushes my soul that those days are vanishing, as if they never existed, oh how i yearn for the 80s and 90s, how i yearn for sitting next to someone i love, eating a meal, drifting away into fantasy-land, dreaming of the alien world ahead of me, perhaps we dont deserve such magic anymore, perhaps we never did, perhaps it was i that never deserved it

>>18866374
>how the fuck are they thin?
i lived in japan for 12 years
here's the quick rundown

>walk literally everywhere
>culture pushes almost everyone into being part of a sports club or fitness activity
>small portions (a "meal" in japan is 400~600kcal)
>smaller everything (a typical 'large' packet of chips in Japan is only 50g)
>they actually hydrate, japs drink unsweetened iced tea (oolong, mugi etc) or green tea constantly
>compulsory Home Ec classes from 4th grade until end of highschool. they learn how to actually cook, like making say miso soup or curry from scratch, how to gut and clean a fish etc
>4h of PE classes a week
>half of their PE classes are theory, where they learn how to count calories, balance healthy meals, how to calculate how much of each vitamin/mineral is in a meal etc
>school sports clubs, jap schools basically bully kids into joining some sort of after school club, which is a 12~20h a week commitment. this continues from age 10 until age 22 or so, until
>office jobs often have a compulsory "volleyball hangout" or some sort of sports thing they do with their coworkers a couple times a month
i could go on but you get the idea

most of it boils down to
>they exercise constantly
>they hydrate well
>all of their food & portions are much smaller

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

>>18871841
My biggest advice is that real, professional tasting is hard, and you shouldn't worry about giving brief or simple tasting notes. Trying to force it doesn't really work. When you're starting out you'll mostly give notes like woody, nutty, earthy etc. as you taste more stuff and have a better calibration, you'll start to find different sorts of flavors that can be consistent across different teas that you'll want to look for words to describe. I think it's fun, but a lot of the cultural and focus around tasting is people like Mei Leaf, who do it as a performance and not as any serious exercise. China has a robust culture around tea tasting and evaluation, but it mostly hasn't been exported from what I've seen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: what's the general difference in taste between small and large leaf ripe pu-erhs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873668
This is very general
Smaller leafs and buds, stronger, more bitter, infuses faster, runs out out flavor in less brews. Larger leaves + stems, sweeter, more mellow, smoother, less strong brews but more of them.
But its going to vary based on processing, fermentation level, the batch of tea leaves used etc.

- not allowing the leaves room to expand, such as using an infuser basket
- adding too many leaves to the pot

Tea beginner here.
I tried and liked Bigelow's oolong, but Twinings is lighter, less earthy, and more of a green tea flavor to it. Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
oolong is one of the most varied categories of tea, because it can be more or less oxidized. the less oxidized stuff is closer to green tea, more oxidized to black tea generally. also, oolong can be roasted to various degrees, which can also change the flavor completely. there are many different types of oolong, some of them can be very fresh and smell of flowers and fruit, while others are bready, nutty, sweet or even minetal in taste

you generally shouldn't buy tea by prepackaged supermarket brands if you want to buy good quality stuff. you should be buying it from trusted vendors, who you can find in the pastebin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
>Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
yes you can get big variation in tea picked from the same mountain. oolongs typically come either as fermented 'green tea' or oxidised fermented 'black tea'
>What beginner-level brands should I look for?
loose will always be better than bagged, get a gaiwan or brewing basket that fits in your mug. vahdam is good for indian and sells on amazon, im guessing as your just starting out you wouldn't want to dive right in to importing from chinese suppliers. look out for iron goddess of mercy/Tieguanyin and Da Hong Pao/Big Red Robe. you'll be able to get both off amazon/tea houses/chinese stores although buying off an actual tea seller will give better quality and probably a little cheaper/quality

>>18870974
>>18870943
They have humans monitoring security cameras. The point of increased automation is that you can have a single human operator managing the operations of say, 5 stores simultaneously. So if Karen walks into the store she can still ask to speak to the manager, but that manager can handle Karens at multiple locations and so is not underutilized as a burger flipper the rest of the day.

Similarly, vandalism or spills can be handled with a rapid response cleanup crew. You don't need instant cleanup response at a single location every five minutes -- you might need 2--4 cleanups at a location per day, so the crews can spread their services around locations, or they can be outsourced to a contractor servicing several different companies in the immediate area so they don't even have to drive around much (thus making it cheaper than doing it in-house).

If you look at the train industry, for example, automation doesn't mean that robots solve every single problem all the time 100% with no oversight -- it means a single person doing oversight and management can do so over many trains and routes at once, instead of a single train or segment of track as in the past.

The opening of McDonald's first fully automated location in Austin, Texas, could potentially signal a shift towards increased automation in the fast food industry. >CEO's and top people are greedy.
This is the real problem. An ACTUAL solution to this would be to implement some sort of percentage cap of the company's yearly revenue that any single person in a given position can take home as income in companies with over a certain number of employees. The more money the company makes, the more money everyone working there makes, higher tier positions still make more, but the disparity between CEO and lowest paid worker is greatly reduced and wealth inequality in the country as a whole would be brought back to reasonable levels pretty quickly. I know there would be a lot of details to hash out in a system like this and the percentages would have to be calculated for each company, I don't think you'd really be able to standardize something like this but if there was a serious effort by the government to regulate and enforce this kind of thing you'd still have people being incentivized to work as hard as they can without leaving an option open for upper management to abuse the rest of the people working there and take home way more money than they really deserve at the expense of everyone else working for them.

I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

posts.com:
>>18877727
All purpose has a long shelf life and you can buy big bags. The cheapest supermarket for basics like flour is gonna be Aldi (US, Europe, etc), Walmart (US), Costco or Sams (US), Lidl (Europe), etc.

You can pre-sift and store your flour by simply pouring slowly through a sieve into a glass or nonreactive container, giving a decent seal, and storing in a dark temperate or cold place. Per >>18877737 freezing does *not* kill most bacteria (including salmonella) or many insect eggs. The likelihood of salmonella or harmful bacteria from flour, however, is extremely slim (statistically almost unmeasurable, in fact -- a study that sampled 20k bags of flour around the US found exactly one with harmful bacteria; insects obviously were not found). Prebaking your flour for eating raw is thus overkill *unless you are immunocompromised or extremely elderly and have something critical to live for* -- the love of your grandchildren doesn't count.

Whole wheat does not have as good of shelf life as white (dehulled) flours and thus is better to buy in the smaller bags and/or store in the freezer unless you bake with it a shitload. I find that for most recipes, except yeasted breads, subbing 50/50 whole wheat to white flour works just as well, and the benefit from whole grains over hulled is pretty well established at this point.

If you're paying a significant premium for bread or self-rising flours, don't bother -- they simply mix in yeast or baking powder and salt beforehand, and you can find the recipes online (self-rising flour is common in Southern recipes as a holdover from the early 1900s).

"Fancy" multi-grain flours may be cheaper to make yourself by, carefully, grinding the grains yourself in a blender. I say carefully because you can overheat dry blending if you go too long, so follow some online instructions.

Those are most of the tips I know of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18878080
For other specialty flours, unless you *need* the *authentic* flavor, you can do easy substitutions. For example:
Graham flour -> whole wheat
Bise -> 50/50 whole wheat + AP
Euro dark rye -> pumpernickel rye (with some modification -- look it up).
Korean wheat -> AP
etc. Just look up cheap substitutions from reliable cooking sites.

I will say that an excellent set of seed-to-flour-to-bread recipes you should look up, that are relatively inexpensive depending on if you buy the seeds and grind or boil+mash yourself (depending on recipe), are sunflower seed breads. Unhyped thus low-cost and solid taste.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877727
>Does unfortified flour taste and bake better than fortified?
No. Fortified anything you buy in the store (except liquor) generally means just adding extra nutrients, which are in such trace amounts that they don't change the flavor in a detectable way. There are probably exceptions, but most of the shit you hear about are urban myths, and if "confirmed" in a test it's almost always not even single-blinded.

Flour bought in a large grocery store will always because its weight is so large and grocery chains are shipped to by dedicated trucks. Anybody else, including you if you order directly, has an enormous markup by weight, or a markup from ordering in smaller packages. The rule is generally the same for anything heavy, with the exception of certain rare ingredients, or from suppliers who specialize in direct-to-consumer shipping (like some online liquor stores), or Black Friday sales.

>Good flour
I don't know what you mean by "good flour". Yes, you can get it right from the miller, and that will probably cost you more (if on transportation alone) since they are not set up as a direct-to-consumer resaler, and I suppose you'll "know where your grain is coming from", as if you can do an inspection yourself. That doesn't mean you'll get consistent protein content from a single milling, as QC would do.

As far as King Arthur flour, be sure not to confuse their "Patent Flour", which is their own thing with the addition of endosperm in the milling, and their All-Purpose which is produced to be somewhat interchangeable with recipes calling for AP (and although theirs has a slightly higher protein content than other name brands, this is not desired in every case: see https://www.americastestkitchen.com/cooksillustrated/articles/596-a-guide-to-all-purpose-flour-shopping-tips-the-best-brands-and-more )

None of this has anything to say about how "good" the flour is in general, just the amount of protein. And unfortunately that particular test does not compare supermarket brands. But in the vast majority of baking you do, as an amateur home chef, the protein count within that acceptable margin for wheat flour won't actually be noticeable to you relative to the margin of error you'll have in the baking process itself as a home cook, so just buy generic and ignore these faggots for now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18878404
Self-rising flour is AP flour + baking powder + salt (KA says it themselves). Bread flour is different, either with different wheat or just with added gluten for a higher protein content overall to give better results for yeast-risen breads. Each brand has a different mark for protein for each, but they should all have separable margins between cake, AP, and bread. That you're finding better results with KA bread flour on yeast-risen products is due to it being bread flour, not KA flour, at this stage of baking.
https://www.bonappetit.com/story/difference-bread-all-purpose-cake-pastry-flour

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18878423
ALSO regarding AP flour, the decision of whether to produce a relatively high or low protein product has more to do with the cooking culture of the region in which the company is based than the "quality" of the product. The majority of daily baked goods in the Southeast USA (where White Lily is based), like biscuits and such, call for lower protein content than the type of goods done in the Northeast USA (where KA is based). Pan-National brands tend to aim for an in-between protein content. Supermarket chain brands' content will likely reflect whether the chain (or its parent) is national or regional. See a full writeup here: https://www.chefdarin.com/2009/08/flour-power/

>>18879090
I have this stuff, which, along with coconut oil is what everyone says to buy to make "movie theater popcorn". I very much disagree with this. Flavacol and coconut oil is what you should buy if you want your stovetop popcorn to taste exactly like microwave popcorn.

If you want good buttered popcorn, in my experience what you want is clarified butter. I would not buy it pre-made, either. The pre-made stuff tasted funky to me. It's easy to make, you just simmer the butter until the solids separate and then pour them off. Butter is really expensive right now, though.

Another tasty butter-based option is to use coconut oil or some other high-smoke-point oil, and then throw some fresh butter in right before it stops popping. This will make brown butter popcorn, which is good with some salt and sugar kettlecorn style. It has to go in right at the end though, or else it will burn.

You are essentially making what's called "aroma oil" in Japan/ramen world. You can get some good ideas if you search that.

The other cuisine that does something similar is Indian cooking. It's called tempering and you get oil super fucking hot then dump it all over a blend of herbs and spices. Once it cools some you pour that oil on top of whatever Indian sloppa you have made.

Both are really excellent additions to their respective foods.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18873015
When I graduated from college, my mom was pretty sickly. Since I was available, it was deemed I'd be the one taking care of her. Nothing too heavy, give her pills, change oxygen tanks for her, cook meals, clean the house, etc. I got to live at home rent free, no job, lots of free time. I didn't have a lot of friends anymore, they were all moving on with their lives, moving away, getting jobs, getting married. But I had time for me. My sleep schedule was kinda shit because my mom would call me in the middle of the night for help with stuff. I watched a lot of late night tv. Specifically Good Eats, which was on from like 2am to 5am. I watched it every night. I learned a lot about cooking. Not just how to make A dish, but the science behind it and related dishes. I learned techniques I hadn't thought of before. I started experimenting more with my cooking. I'd buy new stuff I hadn't tried before, made exotic cuisines and fancy desserts. My mom loved it. It was a lot of fun for me and it turned cooking and baking into a passion I still have someone today. Mom is long gone now, and I don't really have the time and money to make a lot of the stuff I used to. But the spark is still there, buried under old embers, hoping to return one day.

Nice! Without oil the skins get tough and chewy instead of crispy. It really isn't a big deal with the bag shake method I developed.

You can do air fried raviolis as well. I haven't done them because you batter them or some shit. Seems like too much of a pain in the ass for crispy pasta.

Another is chicken wings. You can just coat them in seasoned flour and air fry them. They turn out really crispy. Once they're crispy toss them in your favorite bbq sauce then pop em back in to get the sauce glazed on there, or just dip em up.

For the /fit/ bros among us, this is what I do

>Mix 200g of greek yoghurt with 120g of stevia
>Add 2 eggs and a bit of vanilla, then mix the entire thing
>Add 0kcal chocolate syrup (as much as you like, I go about 30ml), mix
>Add 90g of oatmeal flour (just grind them yourself in a blender), 25g of cocoa powder and as much protein powder as you want (I do 1-2 scoops)
>(Optional) add 50g of pure chocolate you cut up, or chocolate chunks

30 min in the oven and I like to set it for an entire day. Cut in 7 pieces and thats an easy delicious 10+ grams of protein chocolate brownie (for example for breakfast)

>>18869998
It's called cocoa powder. It's in literally every grocery store.

Depending on the brand you can get Dutch-processed or regular, and you should follow what the recipe asks for, because they have different acidity. Generally Dutch-processed is the chocolate flavor people want and expect, which is why it's more common, while non-Dutch processed is used for a little twist on flavor, or if some specific pH optimization is needed, or for color (namely red velvet cake).
https://www.seriouseats.com/difference-dutch-process-natural-cocoa-powder-substitute

The real secret to the soaklill is buy this stuff called powdered brewery wash.

Get water as hot as possible
Plug sink
Add PBW to sink and stir in.
Swish everything around to dissolve PBW.
Let sit overnight.
Drain.
Use the mere pressure from your faucet to perfectly clean everything.

I have a dishwasher now and I love how perfectly clean my glasses get. It's so satisfying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18866973
Former butcher here, don't buy a cow to kill and butcher if you have no experience, breaking down and butchering a cow is an extremely skilled job that you need years of experience to do correctly. First, it takes at least 2 people an entire day to break down a whole cow. You simply won't be able to do it yourself. Three skilled butchers with years of experience can maybe break down 3 halves of cattle in a day; you have absolutely no idea what you're doing and the meat will start going rancid before you've finished a quarter. And this is after they are slaughtered, bled and skinned before being delivered to the butcher. Second, you need a huge, completely sanitized workshop that is refrigerated. If your surfaces aren't perfectly sanitized and the temperature is above 10degrees C your meat will spoil. Third, most beef is air cured for about a week before it's broken down. You will need a huge walk in fridge with rails and hooks to hang your meat and cure it before cutting. Finally, you will need an industrial sized vacuum sealer to package the cuts and a hot water dipper to seal the bags. And most importantly, you literally don't know how to butcher anything and will inevitably ruin perfectly good cuts of meat.

>>18866973
I don't know about cows but I buy a pig from a local farmer once or twice a year along with my parents.
We select the pig when it's still a piglet and it is marked as ours. We go and visit it once in a while as it grows up so we see that it's thriving and having a good life. My niece pets it and feeds it treats.
We usually have a local butcher cut it up for us since he's a friend of the family and gives us a good price. We then have a family day of further processing the parts into mince, pate, bacon, sausages, brawn etc. Dinner that day is porkliver pate on bread and of course the tongue with mustard.
It would be a little cheaper to buy pork on sale at the grocery store, but the quality is better, we know the swine had a good life, and butchering day really is a nice family event.

So yeah, you'll want to look into local farms I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18866973
Search the internet for farms around you. Most farmers haven't figured out to have an internet presence, so taking a drive around the country-side or visiting local or regional farmer's markets is also an option. I lucked out and was able to join a private association to buy grass-fed beef and raw milk directly from a local farmer. We purchased half a cow that I split with my family, it worked out to be around $3.50/lb hanging weight after the processing fee for the butcher. Don't butcher it yourself, you'd probably have to pick up the cow from the farm with a trailer and kill it yourself if you really wanted to do that. At that point you might as well just buy a calf and raise it yourself in your back yard or indoors. The beef we've gotten locally is superior to anything in the grocery store. The flavor is out of this world, very buttery and earthy. My only complaint is that the cuts are fairly small compared to the grocery store, but it's still cheaper per lb buying wholesale cow. Maybe the size of the cuts were bc of how I told the butcher to process it, or because the breed they raise are smaller than other cattle, or because they don't raise them as long before they slaughter them. I don't really mind eating smaller cuts, but that's the biggest complaint I have for my local farmer. Also in general, local meat will always come frozen, even at the farmer's market, it's really not that big of a deal. If you're buying from farmer's market retail, then you'll pay more than the grocery store. We also got a quarter pig last year, worth it 100%. Deep freezer is necessary. Again, don't butcher it yourself plz. Pic not related to half cow, pic is from another local farm.

>>18868221
To add to my post, it's probably more important to find a farmer that uses a trustworthy, local butcher than the actual farmer themselves. There have been many stories of local farmers sending their high quality cows to a butcher and getting shit meat back, different animal received than the one sent in. Also buying via a private association means that the meat is not for sale to the public, and most likely, it is not USDA inspected, so there are looser restrictions on where they can process the meat. My local farmer has an open door/farm 24/7/365 policy where you're welcome to visit anytime as a club member and inspect for yourself what is going on at the farm, state and federal agents are not welcome since it is a private club. Being a private association, they are not allowed to sell to the public at farmer's markets. It saves on costs on public regulation which they pass on to the club members, and it has allowed them to stay in business and not go under as a local family farm. I've been a member for almost 3 years and have always been satisfied with their quality, their chickens are better than any other farmer or grocery store in the region. They have raw milk butter that I don't really care for since it's very grassy and I don't like that flavor in my butter, but if you like Irish butter you'd probably love it. Thanks for listening to my blog post, go meet local farmers and give them your business.

>>18871634
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called Linux, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called Linux distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux!

>>18872856
I believe ideally you should *warm* your non-coated stainless steel(~200°F), add oil, then continue heating to your desired cooking temp(300°-400°F).
Thermic shock and warping will still be an issue if you leave the empty pan unattended and add stuff to it after it's been superheated.
With a ceramic-coated or seasoned cast iron pan I don't think the pore stuff should be a thing and you can add the oil colder.

>>18872050
Cast iron has more mass therefore it has better thermal mass. Why is that important? Let's take one of the most used purposes for cast iron, pan seared steak. In pan searing a steak, surface temperature is critical to making a good sear. Once the steak is placed on the pan, the temperature will drop momentarily as the two surfaces work their way into equalizing their temperatures. A good sear requires maintaining as close temperature of the Maillard Reaction as possible, which is roughly around 357*F but requires a surface temperature greater than that since the steak is colder as both surfaces fight to equalize their temperatures. A cast iron skillet with more thermal mass than a stainless steel skillet will resist that temperature gradient longer than a stainless skillet because stainless steel is both less massive as well as less conductive.

With all that said however, I'm a stainless steel guy simply because itjustwerks™

>>18874654
If you are restoring an old, dirty pan from the flea market or fleabay, then this is good advice for an initial seasoning. If you're trying to build up a long-lasting seasoning this way, you will need to repeat this process many, many times. It can definitely work, but just understand that the natural seasoning in your grandma's pan got there after decades of daily use or use multiple times per day.

IMO, the best advice is to just cook in your pan and the seasoning will tend to build up naturally, but there are two complications. 1) Many ex-teflon users don't really know how to cook with oil and fuck up out of ignorance, and 2) if someone wants to cook meat in a new pan, right away, the seasoning will usually not be tough enough. Since most of the small scale/"boutique" cast iron manufacturers only ship their pan with an initial (thin) layer of seasoning, they tend to get a bad reputation when someone puts a steak into the pan, and then after cooking, they notice a steak-shaped spot where all the seasoning stripped off the cooking surface.

Just cook in the pan a lot. That's it. Even illiterate hillbillies can do it.

Enough scrubbing with dish soap and an abrasive scrubber can certainly affect the seasoning, but I'm sure you have a baking sheet somewhere that has some "stains" on it that are impossible to remove, even after soaking, scrubbing and then a pass in the dishwasher. That is seasoning. It's polymerized oil--it's changed into a different material and can no longer be considered oil.

Also, "patina" is again a different concept. Patina refers to a partially rusted layer of metal, usually black or dark brown rather than the usual tan/red or rust. Patina is more stable than rust, but has nothing to do with seasoning. You can patina a carbon steel knife by just using it normally.

>>18872424
My research led me to discover this perfect recipe for short grain rice, but my rice cooker actually does a better job. My old zoji didn't, but this one does.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

39. We use the term “surrogate activity” to designate an activity that is directed toward an artificial goal that people set up for themselves merely in order to have some goal to work toward, or let us say, merely for the sake of the “fulfillment” that they get from pursuing the goal. Here is a rule of thumb for the identification of surrogate activities. Given a person who devotes much time and energy to the pursuit of goal X, ask yourself this: If he had to devote most of his time and energy to satisfying his biological needs, and if that effort required him to use his physical and mental faculties in a varied and interesting way, would he feel seriously deprived because he did not attain goal X? If the answer is no, then the person’s pursuit of goal X is a surrogate activity. Hirohito’s studies in marine biology clearly constituted a surrogate activity, since it is pretty certain that if Hirohito had had to spend his time working at interesting non-scientific tasks in order to obtain the necessities of life, he would not have felt deprived because he didn’t know all about the anatomy and life-cycles of marine animals. On the other hand the pursuit of sex and love (for example) is not a surrogate activity, because most people, even if their existence were otherwise satisfactory, would feel deprived if they passed their lives without ever having a relationship with a member of the opposite sex. (But pursuit of an excessive amount of sex, more than one really needs, can be a surrogate activity.)

When i was moving to minnesota I stopped at a Hyvee and liked it so much that I immediately googled whether there would be any near where I was living. They exist in minnesota but not where I live.

Mexican food is fine in the midwest. I've been all over the country from NYC to some real cowtowns and decent mexican food/grocery stores are a constant. Vietnamese food is also getting pretty easy to find though quality varies, and good banh mi is harder to find than good pho.

The real thing that I miss about CA/HI is the japanese grocery stores, there are korean stores in the midwest will carry 95% of the products that I want but they don't have the prepared foods.

The local foods do grow on you after a while.

Overall, though, if you have a regular grocery store/walmart near you you'll be fine as long as you can cook. If you're a foodie that eats out a lot and loves to complain, though, just rope now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Des Moines:
Bunch of good Vietnamese places due to the number of Vietnamese immigrants that moved there. I liked pho 888 best.
When I lived there although A Dong and C Fresh Market (an Asian grocery store with a small restaurant inside) were good too. There were good authentic Mexican places too although I can't remember their names. You had to travel to Ames for top notch Chinese, but that may have changed since I last lived there 8 years ago.
Zombie Burger (it's a zombie themed meme restaurant but the burgers are great)
Alpine Tap was my favorite bar.


Iowa City:
La Regia Taqueria (Mexican)
Szechuan House (authentic Chinese)
Deadwood (the best bar)
Mesa Pizza is probably my favorite pizza place.

Davenport (Quad Cities Area) I live here now:
Quad Cities style pizza (I prefer Harris but there are a number of places serving it). Happy Joe's (not Quad Cities style) invented taco pizza and theirs is really good. Lopiez is my favorite pizza place and serves NY style pizza.
The best Indian food is at a gas station in Moline (it's across the river from Davenport) called Preet Mini Mart. Check their schedule. I go on Thursday or Friday if I'm in that area for estate sales, but they might only serve the Indian food a few days a week.
There's a really good Vietnamese restaurant inside of Oriental Food Store in Davenport that's only open weekends. Oriental Food Store is the best Asian grocery on the Iowa side of the Quad Cities. T&T Asian Foods Market is the best Asian grocery on the Illinois side and has a bigger selection. I usually go there when I need noodles.
If you want authentic Chinese, I think the only place that serves it is 888 Bistro in Moline. Ask for the authentic menu.
Abarrotes Carrillo is a Mexican grocery store/restaurant.
Ross' Restaurant (get the Magic Mountain)
My favorite bar is Geezer's which is a total dive
HOOTERS

You've already smelled the food you a cooking for the entire time you are cooking it. You are over saturated with that food's aroma. This is why so many people realize they are not hungry after cooking a meal for their family. It's not they are snacking while cooking, but that their noses are saturated (flavor mostly comes through smell) and are no longer interested in that food.

Increase the time and space between and consumption. Make a meal and take a walk outside while the food is being held hot, and then don't eat in your kitchen but in another room (not your bedroom you fatass).

It's not as satisfying but cook enough food for couple of meals and then chill it and eat it the next day and the day after. Your sense of smell and taste won't be use to it.

I'm not sure how many actual professionals are in this thread or on /ck/. If you think wearing nitrile gloves is a sign of an amateur, that is actually a sign that you're an amateur.

In most places it is THE LAW that you must wear gloves while handling ready-to-eat foods. That's just one thing... I guess Subway sandwich artists wear those giant retarded vinyl things... but nitrile is the best.

Not just that, but when you're prepping things in high volume, a good nitrile glove protects your hands. If you've never broken down chickens or chopped multiple 40 lb cases of veg, than I'm not surprised that you're not aware that gloves will protect your hands from getting impacted with raw foods. That shit can cause pretty painful infections.

Also, as stated previously in this thread, the color of gloves mean nothing. Black? OK. Sometimes you can get good deals on other colors, usually they are the same price.

posts.com:
I love all your soups. I've had almost all of them and will make the ones I haven't. But we are talking GOAT here. And there is no soup more well known, comforting, or beloved as the humble chicken noodle soup. Everyone has had a cold and almost all of us have had bowl of chicken soup with it. If such a thing as comfort kino exists then that feeling every one of you got when you thought about that warm bowl on a cold night is it.

In all my life whenever I generally feel shitty chicken noodle has been there for me. All soups are beautiful. But there is only one chicken noodle.
posts.filename: the most humble dish of all

Trying to remember off the top of my head
>1lb of chicken breast sliced into strips
>2 zuchini thinly sliced
>1 whole onion thinly sliced
>half a cup of fresh tarragon finely chopped
>juice and zest of two small or 1 large lemon
>2 tsp of minced garlic
>one jar of creme fraiche
1 cup of mastacholi pasta
>sear the chicken breast
>add onion and zuchini. Stir until golden
>add garlic and tarragon. Stir for an additional minute
>add lemon and creme fraiche. Put back on burner until warm but not boiling
>garnish with fresh tarragon and parmesan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18876142
That's not pathogenic food poisoning. That's either a food allergy, or you got something with a spoiled ingredient in it. Food poisoning of the type caused by bacterial pathogens takes time to develop. The bacteria need time to reproduce to the point where there is an immune response. This is the incubation period, as seen in any other sort of infection like the flu. You don't start experiencing symptoms of the flu the instant you inhale a couple of virus particles. It takes time for the virus to incubate and make you sick. Same for salmonella, any of the vibrios, shigella, et al. If you get sick within minutes of eating, you were either already sick, are having an allergic reaction, or ate spoiled food. Food poisoning is not instantaneous.

>prosciutto
here you go
Prosciutto is made from high-quality pork legs. The meat is covered in salt and left to rest for a few weeks. During this time, the salt draws out blood and moisture, which prevents bacteria from entering the meat (and is why it's safe for us to eat it "raw"). Salting the meat also causes the flavors to become more concentrated.

After the salting process, the pork legs are washed, seasoned by hand (often according to a secret family recipe), and left to dry-age at a controlled temperature for 14 to 36 months. It is the combination of salt, air, and time that gives prosciutto its sweet and delicate flavor.

Apeaking as an Italian, making prosciutto requires quite a bit. You need to take a whole pork leg, cure and salt it, you need to hang it in a cellar for months or even years and to know/learn how to check it to see if it is going good. And in the end you get several kgs of prosciutto, so unless you are doing this for the whole extended family it is much better to buy some.
If you want to try to learn I suggest starting smaller, like salame or lucanica.

posts.com:
>>18870519
You will need a sanitized space where you can accurately measure and control the temperature and humidity. Anon here >>18870552 describes the process simply and this is more or less the gist of it. You will need to salt and use nitrites to cure a high quality large ham that's been skinned, boned and trimmed. DESU home dry-curing meats simply isn't worth the investment unless you live in a particularly dry environment because of the time you need to invest into curing it and maintaining an appropriate temperature and humidity level or else it'll spoil which is the reason there aren't many "how to" guides online. That's why northern countries historically have wet-cured pork through brining to make it into bacon, English ham etc., which is also more economical in that the process might take a week instead of a year minimum. This is why countries that dry-cure ham typically only use small slices of it and the reason that it costs a lot more than bacon. If you somehow have a huge surplus of pork and you live in a northern climate it's much more practical to learn how to brine bacon or smoke sausages.
